data.text: @TheLawyerCraig @bradywendeln @CDCgov @OurWorldInData That will be updated so I would wait on that call, the bigger miss that’s presumably accurate is we were way off on delta. It looks like it was much deadlier than reported.

@TheLawyerCraig OWID seems to only report deaths when they are reasonably accurate. So US data may be from a month to month and a half ago while some European countries are from a week ago. Most countries have no material adjustment once reported.

@TheLawyerCraig @bradywendeln @CDCgov @OurWorldInData someone must have done that analysis - i think it can take up to 6 months for all the official death records to be counted by CDC (but not sure the % that represents)  Will keep an eye on the omicron wave over the next weeks.

@raypal @bradywendeln @CDCgov @OurWorldInData I know it always looks like it's dropping *recently*. But how much revision still goes on 8/10/12 weeks later? No doubt some (and even some months before that), but at what point are 90%, or 95%, or 98% of excess deaths captured?
@TheLawyerCraig @bradywendeln @CDCgov @OurWorldInData December is too recent not be revised up later, so I would revisit this in 3 months. Excess death data always looks like it's dropping.

@bradywendeln @CDCgov @OurWorldInData I think that's right. They're definitely seeing that in the UK & Denmark. Our matching criteria probably varies, but pre-Covid winter always came with death from issues that are Covid-like. Now add in 30-50% of the population testing positive in a 2-month span? Could add C19.

@TheLawyerCraig @CDCgov @OurWorldInData So dying from Covid (as opposed to “with”) was seemingly pretty accurate until recently with Omicron. We are getting more “with” Covid deaths, which may not have actually been the real cause of death. Which I think is great news for getting back to normal… correct?

@bradywendeln @CDCgov @OurWorldInData Assuming there isn't a lot of revision to excess deaths from January 9 or before, the divergence in Dec/Jan from an otherwise direct (& slightly delayed) relationship for all other waves could mean that Omi's massive infections may have led us to over-attribute deaths to Covid.
@TheLawyerCraig @CDCgov @OurWorldInData What’s your take? Seems obvious, but would like to hear.
